etymology.description: 有(有) (yǒu, "have"), 位(位) (wèi, "seat"), 子(子) (zi, "noun suffix"), 吗(嗎) (ma, "question particle")
etymology.interpretation: This phrase is a question asking whether there is an available seat. 有(有) (yǒu, "have") indicates possession or availability, 位(位) (wèi, "seat") refers to a place to sit, and 吗(嗎) (ma, "question particle") is used to form yes-no questions. The 子(子) (zi, "noun suffix") is used here to make 位(位) (wèi, "seat") into a more casual expression.

examples.chinese: 走进餐厅时(走進餐廳時)，你可以问服务员(你可以問服務員)：有位子吗(有位子嗎)？
examples.pinyin: zǒu jìn cāntīng shí, nǐ kěyǐ wèn fúwùyuán: yǒu wèi zi ma?
examples.english: When you walk into a restaurant, you can ask the waiter: Is there a seat available?

examples.chinese: 到达咖啡馆时(到達咖啡館時)，请问有位子吗(請問有位子嗎)？
examples.pinyin: dào dá kāfēiguǎn shí, qǐng wèn yǒu wèi zi ma?
examples.english: When you arrive at the café, please ask: Is there a seat available?

examples.chinese: 你到图书馆(你到圖書館)，问问管理员(問問管理員)：有位子吗(有位子嗎)？
examples.pinyin: nǐ dào túshūguǎn, wèn wèn guǎnlǐyuán: yǒu wèi zi ma?
examples.english: When you get to the library, ask the administrator: Is there a seat available?
